docs.lead_paragraph: Miriam's new smile is wide and pretty, with large, white, perfectly spaced teeth. Before she had her front teeth covered with porcelain veneers, they were crooked, worn at the tips and stained at the roots. Carl's new mouth looks a lot like Miriam's, with pearly whites in an even row, a clear improvement over the yellowed, faded smile he had before.

headline.main: Sometimes, Your New Smile Will Make You Frown

docs.abstract: Porcelain veneers are growing in popularity as quick fix to imperfect smiles, but procedure can be problematic and some patients are unsatisfied with end result; American Academy of Cosmetic Dentistry reports that dentists are doing two and half times as many veneers as in 1990's and group president Dr Lawrence Addleson asserts that patients must be diligent and find best care they can; veneers are not reversible, but can be redone; procedure and possible complications described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Veneers, porcelain shells bonded to the front side of the teeth, may not provide smiles as pretty as expected.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Maire Connolly learned about the tsunami on Dec. 26, she was torn: should she leave her family in Ireland to return to the World Health Organization in Geneva, where she leads the team that responds to health problems after natural disasters? Or should she stay with her parents, whom she rarely sees because of her work? Technology made the decision easier. Dr. Connolly stayed in Ireland and spoke by telephone most of each day with her deputy, Dr. Michelle Gayer, in Geneva.

headline.main: From a Far Continent, Victims' Needs Beckon. But So Does Her Family.

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Maire Connolly, head of World Health Organization team that responds to health problems after natural disasters, about her work and impact of recent deadly tsunami in Indian Ocean; Connolly, who is home with her family in Ireland for holidays, describes balance between very important global work and family life; specific challenges to providing aid for devastated region discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The dilemma faced by one doctor after the disasters in Asia: stay with her family or lend her expertise.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.lead_paragraph: How desperate are overweight people to shed their extra pounds? Desperate enough that they are willing to risk death. And so desperate that they value losing weight as much as severely depressed patients value relief from their illness, a new survey has found.

headline.main: Longing to Lose, at a Cost

docs.abstract: Dr Christina C Wee, Harvard Medical School internist, conducts survey on how desperate overweight people may become to lose weight; survey findings, published in Journal of General Internal Medicine, show that 19 percent of overweight and 33 percent of obese individuals would risk death for even 10 percent weight loss; given greater opportunity to lose weight, obese and overweight people will sometimes assume even more risk of death or shortened life span (S)
docs.snippet: How desperate are overweight people to shed their extra pounds? Desperate enough that they are willing to risk death.

docs.lead_paragraph: An exceptionally health-conscious friend throws out any food that has passed the date stamped on the package. She has little understanding of what these dates mean and how they may affect the freshness or safety of the food in question. And she is not alone. Dates on foods come in many different forms, and confusion about what they mean is widespread. Only a few reflect the safety of consuming a food past the stamped-on date.

headline.main: When Your Prunes Have Passed Their Prime

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses dates placed on packaging and interprets their meaning for consumers; meaning of terms, such as packed on, sell by, best if used by and expiration, explained; general guidelines for pantry foods and frozen foods also discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: "Sell by Jan 05." Should you buy it? A primer on those hieroglyphs on bottles, cans and cartons.

docs.lead_paragraph: It may be an obvious fact that hot things in the kitchen and children do not mix. But emergency room workers find that some parents still do not understand the problem. Researchers reported yesterday that burns, and especially scaldings, remain common for children, despite years of efforts to educate parents. The study, which appears in Pediatrics, was written by Dorothy A. Drago, a product safety consultant based in Massachusetts.

headline.main: Of Hot Pots and Back Burners

docs.abstract: Dorothy A Drago, product safety consultant, compiles study that shows burns remain common source of emergency room visits for children despite years of efforts to educate parents on ways to prevent them; federal Consumer Product Safety Commission surveillance program gathered emergency room injury records from 100 hospitals and Drago's review of those records finds that over six years more than 17,000 children age 5 and under were treated for burns caused by non-electric cookware; scaldings remain most critical problem and research urges parents to use back burners and turn handles away from side; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: It may be an obvious fact that hot things in the kitchen and children do not mix. But emergency room workers find that some parents still do not understand the problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Never talk on the telephone during a thunderstorm. THE FACTS -- It's been around so long that few people take it seriously. But the claim that chatting on the phone in a thunderstorm can electrocute you is no urban legend. A bolt of lightning that strikes a telephone line can cause an electrical surge to shoot through the wires and enter a handset.
docs.abstract: In rare instances lightning can travel through telephone lines and cause electrocution; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A bolt of lightning that strikes a telephone line can cause an electrical surge to shoot through the wires and enter a handset, but the odds are small.

docs.lead_paragraph: With obesity much on Americans' minds, an entire industry has sprung up selling diets and diet books, meal replacements and exercise programs, nutritional supplements and Internet-based coaching, all in an effort to help people lose weight. But a new study, published today, finds little evidence that commercial weight-loss programs are effective in helping people drop excess pounds. Almost no rigorous studies of the programs have been carried out, the researchers report. And federal officials say that companies are often unwilling to conduct such studies, arguing that they are in the business of treatment, not research.

headline.main: Diet and Lose Weight? Scientists Say 'Prove It!'

docs.abstract: Commercial weight-loss industry, which has grown immensely over past few decades, is often criticized by scientific community for selling services and products without substantial studies to demonstrate effectiveness of programs for losing weight; Dr Thomas Wadden, University of Pennsylvania weight and eating disorders program director, leads new study that finds Weight Watchers to be only commercial program to publish reliable data from randomized trials; study, published in Annals of Internal Medicine, calls for more disclosure and studies to provide consumers with tools to make educated choices; photo (L)
docs.snippet: A new study finds little evidence that commercial weight-loss programs help people drop excess pounds.

docs.lead_paragraph: Diets rich in fruit, vegetables and low-fat dairy have been shown in some studies to help reduce blood pressure in adults. Now, a new study in the journal Epidemiology suggests that children may benefit as well. The researchers followed the health of a group of children, initially ages 3 to 6, for eight years. Their findings suggest that paying attention to what children eat can play an important role in decreasing their risk of hypertension in later years.
docs.abstract: Dr Lynn L Moore of Boston University School of Medicine leads study that analyzes data on children participating in Framingham Children's Study; findings, published in journal Epidemiology, suggest that children are less likely to develop high blood pressure, if they have diets rich in fruits, vegetables, and dairy products; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that children may benefit from diets rich in fruit, vegetables and low-fat dairy.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who drink and drive may be at higher risk for accidents in part because the alcohol makes it harder to perceive depth, new research has found. The study, which appears in the current issue of Psychological Science, explored depth perception that is tied to movement, called motion parallax, not the better-known kind of depth perception that people enjoy because of binocular vision.

headline.main: Drunk, and Out of Your Depth

docs.abstract: Dr Mark Nawrot of North Dakota State University leads research into effects of alcohol on driver's ability to judge depth while in motion; study, published in Psychological Science, suggest drivers have significantly impaired spatial perception after moderate alcohol consumption, which places them at higher risk for accidents (S)
docs.snippet: People who drink and drive may be at higher risk for accidents in part because the alcohol makes it harder to perceive depth, new research has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: It does not look like anyone's mother, and the baby it delivers has none of the emotional appeal of a newborn. But a lifelike birth simulator developed at Johns Hopkins University may provide some important new information about problem deliveries in real mothers and infants. The birth simulator, which started out as a research project in engineering, has now been used to determine the best way to deliver a baby whose shoulders become stuck in the birth canal, a condition called shoulder dystocia.

headline.main: Device Allows Doctors To Practice Deliveries

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Allen, Johns Hopkins University biomedical engineering professor, heads project that developed lifelike birth simulator for training and research; Dr Edith Gurewitsch, obstetrics and gynecology assistant professor, is working with team to test machine in difficult births involving shoulder dystocia; early findings, published in American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, suggest that Rubin's maneuver, which rotates baby's trunk, uses half force of most commonly used delivery technique to deliver baby with shoulders stuck in birth canal; benefits of simulator discussed (M)
docs.snippet: The birth simulator has now been used to determine the best way to deliver a baby whose shoulders become stuck in the birth canal.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN JOURNAL OF OBSTETRICS AND GYNECOLOGY
